title: 114_s2109
content: The Act titled "Directing Dollars to Disaster Relief Act of 2015" defines key terms such as administrative cost, Administrator, Agency, and hazard mitigation program. Administrative cost refers to costs incurred by the Agency for disaster assistance, while direct administrative cost is specific to grantees or subgrantees under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The "Directing Dollars to Disaster Relief Act of 2015" defines terms related to disaster assistance programs, including hazard mitigation program, individual assistance program, major disaster, and mission assignment. The "Directing Dollars to Disaster Relief Act of 2015" defines terms related to disaster assistance programs and mandates the development of an integrated plan to control and reduce administrative costs for major disasters within 365 days of enactment. This plan includes steps, milestones, and strategic goals for reducing administrative costs annually. The "Directing Dollars to Disaster Relief Act of 2015" mandates the development of an integrated plan to control and reduce administrative costs for major disasters, including clear roles, responsibilities, and a timetable for implementation. It also requires comparing costs and benefits of tracking administrative cost data by different programs and clarifying guidance for claiming direct administrative costs. The Administrator must brief the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs within 90 days of enactment. The Administrator is required to develop a plan for disaster relief cost control and submit updates to Congress if modifications are made. Additionally, an annual report must be submitted to Congress for 7 years detailing the development progress. The House of Representatives receives annual reports on the integrated plan development and implementation. Updates are required every 3 and 5 years after the initial report submission. Reports must include total administrative costs spent and average annual percentage of administrative costs. The annual report to Congress must include the average annual percentage of administrative costs, an assessment of plan effectiveness, analysis of strategic goal achievement, identified actions for improvement, and any feasible data tracking. The report must be made public within 30 days of submission to Congress. The Administrator must publicly release the report on the Agency's website after submitting it to Congress.
